questions.q: The most common cardiovascular change in older adults is:
questions.rationale: Aging causes arterial stiffening (arteriosclerosis) leading to increased systolic blood pressure and widened pulse pressure.

questions.q: Age-related changes to the respiratory system include:
questions.rationale: Aging decreases alveolar surface area and lung elasticity, leading to decreased efficiency of gas exchange.

questions.q: Which renal change occurs with normal aging?
questions.rationale: By age 80, approximately 50% of nephrons are lost, reducing GFR and the ability to concentrate urine.

questions.q: Age-related GI changes include all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: Aging decreases stomach acid (HCl) production, which can impair nutrient absorption — particularly B12, iron, and calcium.

questions.q: The most common visual change in older adults is:
questions.rationale: Presbyopia (difficulty focusing on near objects) is a universal age-related change due to loss of lens elasticity.

questions.q: Presbycusis refers to:
questions.rationale: Presbycusis is sensorineural hearing loss associated with aging, particularly affecting high-frequency sounds.

questions.q: Musculoskeletal changes in aging include:
options: Decreased bone density and muscle mass
questions.rationale: Aging causes loss of bone density (osteopenia/osteoporosis) and sarcopenia (loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength).

questions.q: Skin changes in the elderly include all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: Aging decreases skin elasticity (loss of collagen and elastin), making skin more fragile and prone to tearing.

questions.q: Normal aging affects the immune system by:
questions.rationale: Immunosenescence causes decreased T-cell function, impaired antibody response, and increased susceptibility to infections.

questions.q: An older adult's thermoregulatory changes include:
options: Increased risk for both hypothermia and hyperthermia
questions.rationale: Aging impairs the body's ability to regulate temperature due to decreased subcutaneous fat, reduced sweat gland activity, and altered vasoconstriction.

questions.q: The endocrine system in older adults is characterized by:
questions.rationale: Thyroid function decreases with age. Additionally, insulin resistance increases and growth hormone levels decline.

questions.q: Normal neurological changes in aging include:
questions.rationale: Normal aging is associated with slower processing speed, decreased short-term memory, and slower reaction times — though intelligence is generally preserved.

questions.q: Bladder changes in older adults include:
options: Decreased bladder capacity and increased residual volume
questions.rationale: Aging reduces bladder capacity, weakens sphincter tone, and increases post-void residual volume — contributing to incontinence and UTI risk.

questions.q: An older adult is MOST at risk for which type of fracture?
questions.rationale: Hip fractures are the most common and serious fracture in older adults due to osteoporosis and increased fall risk.

questions.q: Which age-related eye condition causes increased intraocular pressure?
questions.rationale: Glaucoma involves increased intraocular pressure that can damage the optic nerve and cause peripheral vision loss.

questions.q: The KEY difference between delirium and dementia is:
options: Delirium is irreversible; dementia is reversible
Delirium has acute onset; dementia has gradual onset
Delirium has stable course; dementia fluctuates
Both have the same onset and course
questions.rationale: Delirium develops acutely (hours to days) and is often reversible. Dementia develops gradually over months to years and is typically progressive.

questions.q: A patient who was oriented yesterday is now confused, agitated, and pulling at their IV. This MOST likely indicates:
questions.rationale: Acute onset of confusion and agitation is the hallmark of delirium, which requires immediate investigation of the underlying cause.

questions.q: Common causes of delirium in older adults include all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: Alzheimer's disease causes dementia, not delirium. Delirium is caused by acute, reversible factors: infection, medications, dehydration, hypoxia, pain.

questions.q: Sundowning syndrome is characterized by:
options: Increased confusion and agitation in the morning
Increased confusion and agitation in the late afternoon/evening
questions.rationale: Sundowning involves increased confusion, restlessness, and agitation in the late afternoon and evening, common in dementia patients.

questions.q: Nursing interventions for sundowning include all EXCEPT:
options: Providing bright artificial lighting at night
questions.rationale: Bright lighting at night disrupts circadian rhythm. Dim, calming environments in the evening help reduce sundowning symptoms.

questions.q: The 4 A's of Alzheimer's disease are:
questions.rationale: The 4 A's: Aphasia (language difficulty), Apraxia (inability to perform motor tasks), Agnosia (inability to recognize objects/people), Amnesia (memory loss).

questions.q: Which type of dementia is characterized by visual hallucinations and Parkinsonian features?
questions.rationale: Lewy body dementia is distinguished by visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and Parkinsonian symptoms (rigidity, shuffling gait).

questions.q: Vascular dementia differs from Alzheimer's in that it:
questions.rationale: Vascular dementia progresses in a stepwise pattern, worsening after each cerebrovascular event (stroke/TIA), unlike the gradual decline of Alzheimer's.

questions.q: Depression in older adults often presents as:
questions.rationale: Older adults with depression often present with physical complaints (pain, fatigue, GI problems) rather than expressing sadness. Pseudodementia (cognitive symptoms) may mimic dementia.

questions.q: Which statement about depression in the elderly is TRUE?
options: It is a normal part of aging
It is often underdiagnosed and undertreated
It does not increase suicide risk
Antidepressants are ineffective in older adults
questions.rationale: Depression is NOT normal aging. It is frequently underdiagnosed in older adults, and elderly white males have the highest suicide rate of any demographic.

questions.q: Donepezil (Aricept) is prescribed for Alzheimer's disease to:
options: Slow cognitive decline by increasing acetylcholine
questions.rationale: Donepezil is a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine levels, temporarily slowing cognitive decline. It does not cure or reverse the disease.

questions.q: Memantine (Namenda) works by:
questions.rationale: Memantine blocks NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitotoxicity. It is used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.

questions.q: When communicating with a patient who has dementia, the nurse should:
options: Use complex sentences for better understanding
Speak quickly to maintain the patient's attention
Use simple sentences, face the patient, and allow extra time
Correct the patient's errors to maintain orientation
questions.rationale: Simple, direct communication with face-to-face contact and adequate response time reduces frustration and improves understanding.

questions.q: An older adult patient says, 'I just don't see the point in living anymore.' The BEST nursing response is:
options: You have so much to live for!
Are you thinking about hurting yourself?
Let's talk about something more pleasant
questions.rationale: Direct assessment of suicidal ideation is essential. Asking directly about intent does NOT increase suicide risk and allows for appropriate intervention.

questions.q: Which is a common side effect of cholinesterase inhibitors in elderly patients?
questions.rationale: Cholinesterase inhibitors increase acetylcholine, which stimulates the GI tract, commonly causing nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting.

questions.q: The MOST common cause of injury in older adults is:
questions.rationale: Falls are the leading cause of injury, hospital admissions for trauma, and injury-related death in adults over 65.

questions.q: Fall prevention for older adults includes all EXCEPT:
options: Physical restraints as a first-line measure
questions.rationale: Restraints are a LAST resort and actually increase injury risk. Environmental modifications and exercise are first-line fall prevention.

questions.q: Polypharmacy is defined as:
options: The use of multiple medications concurrently, often 5 or more
Taking one medication at multiple times per day
questions.rationale: Polypharmacy (typically defined as 5+ concurrent medications) increases the risk of drug interactions, adverse effects, and non-adherence.

questions.q: The Beers Criteria identifies:
options: Medications that are safe for all age groups
Potentially inappropriate medications for older adults
questions.rationale: The Beers Criteria lists medications that are potentially inappropriate for older adults due to increased risk of adverse effects.

questions.q: Which medication on the Beers Criteria list should be AVOIDED in older adults?
questions.rationale: Diphenhydramine has strong anticholinergic effects (confusion, urinary retention, constipation, dry mouth) and is on the Beers list for older adults.

questions.q: Anticholinergic side effects in older adults include all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: Anticholinergic effects: Dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation (not diarrhea), blurred vision, confusion, tachycardia.

questions.q: When teaching an older adult about medications, the nurse should:
options: Use large print, written instructions and teach-back method
Assume the patient understands the label
questions.rationale: Large print accommodates visual changes, written instructions serve as reference, and teach-back verifies understanding.

questions.q: An older adult is at increased risk for drug toxicity because of:
options: Decreased liver and kidney function affecting drug clearance
questions.rationale: Age-related declines in hepatic metabolism and renal clearance cause drugs to remain in the body longer, increasing toxicity risk.

questions.q: Which class of medications poses the HIGHEST fall risk in older adults?
questions.rationale: Benzodiazepines cause sedation, impaired balance, and confusion — all major fall risk factors. They are on the Beers Criteria.

questions.q: Orthostatic hypotension in older adults is BEST managed by:
options: Rising slowly from lying to sitting to standing
questions.rationale: Gradual position changes allow the cardiovascular system time to compensate for blood pressure shifts.

questions.q: Signs of elder abuse include all EXCEPT:
options: Unexplained bruising in various stages of healing
questions.rationale: Consistent weight and positive affect are signs of adequate care. Abuse indicators include unexplained injuries, fear, neglect, and weight loss.

questions.q: A nurse suspects elder neglect. The nurse is LEGALLY required to:
options: Document and wait for further evidence
questions.rationale: Nurses are mandated reporters. Suspected abuse or neglect must be reported to Adult Protective Services immediately.

questions.q: The most common type of elder abuse is:
questions.rationale: Neglect (failure to provide basic needs: food, shelter, hygiene, medical care) is the most prevalent form of elder abuse.

questions.q: Urinary incontinence in older adults:
options: Is a normal part of aging that cannot be treated
Is often treatable with behavioral interventions
questions.rationale: Incontinence is NOT normal aging. Behavioral interventions (bladder training, pelvic floor exercises, scheduled toileting) are effective first-line treatments.

questions.q: Kegel exercises are used to:
questions.rationale: Kegel exercises strengthen the pelvic floor muscles, helping manage urinary incontinence — particularly stress incontinence.

questions.q: The nurse is caring for an older adult with a new hearing aid. Which instruction is MOST important?
options: Insert it with clean, dry hands and start in quiet environments
questions.rationale: New hearing aid users should start in quiet environments to adjust gradually. Clean, dry handling prevents device damage and ear infections.

questions.q: Sleep changes in older adults include:
options: Decreased total sleep time and more frequent awakenings
questions.rationale: Older adults experience less deep sleep (Stage 3/4), more frequent nighttime awakenings, and decreased total sleep time.

questions.q: Which nutritional concern is MOST common in older adults?
questions.rationale: Dehydration is extremely common in older adults due to decreased thirst sensation, decreased kidney function, and medication effects.

questions.q: An older adult with osteoporosis should be advised to:
options: Take high-dose calcium without vitamin D
Rest in bed as much as possible
questions.rationale: Weight-bearing exercise (walking, dancing, stairs) stimulates bone formation and slows osteoporosis progression.

questions.q: Constipation in older adults is BEST prevented by:
options: Increased fiber, fluids, and physical activity
questions.rationale: Dietary fiber (25-30g/day), adequate fluids (1500-2000mL/day), and regular physical activity promote healthy bowel function.

questions.q: Atypical presentation of MI in an older adult may include:
options: Confusion, dyspnea, or fatigue without chest pain
questions.rationale: Older adults often present with atypical MI symptoms: confusion, weakness, dyspnea, or syncope — without the classic chest pain.

questions.q: A UTI in an older adult may present as:
questions.rationale: In older adults, UTIs frequently present as acute confusion, agitation, or behavioral changes rather than classic urinary symptoms.

questions.q: Pneumonia in an older adult may present atypically with:
questions.rationale: Older adults may not mount a fever with infection. Pneumonia may present with confusion, falls, tachypnea, or functional decline.

questions.q: An older adult with appendicitis may present with:
options: Classic right lower quadrant pain with rebound tenderness
Vague abdominal pain with minimal tenderness
questions.rationale: Older adults often have diminished pain perception and inflammatory response, leading to vague, diffuse abdominal symptoms rather than classic localized pain.

questions.q: Hyperthyroidism in older adults may present as:
options: Apathetic hyperthyroidism with weight loss and atrial fibrillation
questions.rationale: Older adults may have 'apathetic thyrotoxicosis' presenting with fatigue, weight loss, depression, and atrial fibrillation rather than classic hypermetabolic symptoms.

questions.q: An advance directive should be discussed:
options: Only when the patient is terminally ill
Upon admission to any healthcare facility
Only if the family requests it
questions.rationale: The Patient Self-Determination Act requires healthcare facilities to inform patients about advance directives upon admission.

questions.q: A living will specifies:
options: The patient's wishes for end-of-life medical treatment
questions.rationale: A living will documents the patient's wishes regarding life-sustaining treatments in the event they cannot communicate.

questions.q: A healthcare power of attorney (HCPOA) designates:
options: A person to make healthcare decisions when the patient cannot
questions.rationale: HCPOA designates a trusted person (healthcare proxy) to make medical decisions if the patient becomes incapacitated.

questions.q: Hospice care focuses on:
options: Comfort care and quality of life
questions.rationale: Hospice provides holistic comfort care (physical, emotional, spiritual) for terminally ill patients with a prognosis of 6 months or less.

questions.q: A patient with a DNR order develops cardiac arrest. The nurse should:
options: Provide comfort measures and do NOT initiate CPR
questions.rationale: A DNR order means no CPR or resuscitation measures. The nurse provides comfort care and supports the patient and family.

questions.q: Kübler-Ross stages of grief include all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: Kübler-Ross stages: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, Acceptance. Euphoria is not one of the stages.

questions.q: During the dying process, the LAST sense to be lost is:
questions.rationale: Hearing is believed to be the last sense to fade during the dying process. Nurses should continue speaking to the patient.

questions.q: Cheyne-Stokes respirations in a dying patient indicate:
questions.rationale: Cheyne-Stokes (alternating deep and shallow breathing with apnea periods) is a common pattern as death approaches.

questions.q: Post-mortem care includes all EXCEPT:
options: Removing all tubes and lines per policy
Allowing family time with the body
Immediately transporting to the morgue without family notification
questions.rationale: Family should be given time with the body for grieving. Rushing to the morgue without family notification is inappropriate.

questions.q: Palliative care differs from hospice in that palliative care:
options: Can be provided alongside curative treatment
questions.rationale: Palliative care focuses on symptom relief and quality of life and can be provided at ANY stage of illness, alongside curative treatment.

questions.q: Recommended health screenings for adults over 65 include:
options: Mammogram only if family history present
questions.rationale: Annual influenza vaccine and pneumococcal vaccine (PCV20 or PCV15+PPSV23) are recommended for all adults 65 and older.

questions.q: The shingles (herpes zoster) vaccine is recommended for adults age:
questions.rationale: The recombinant zoster vaccine (Shingrix) is recommended for adults 50 and older, regardless of prior shingles or varicella history.

questions.q: Bone density screening (DEXA scan) is recommended for women starting at age:
questions.rationale: DEXA screening is recommended for all women at age 65 and for younger postmenopausal women with risk factors.

questions.q: Which vaccine should older adults receive annually?
questions.rationale: The influenza vaccine is recommended annually for all adults, especially those 65 and older who are at higher risk for complications.

questions.q: Age-appropriate cancer screenings for older adults include:
options: PSA testing is mandatory for all men over 70
Colorectal cancer screening through age 75 (shared decision-making 76-85)
questions.rationale: Colorectal cancer screening is recommended through age 75, with shared decision-making for ages 76-85 based on overall health.

questions.q: Which exercise is MOST beneficial for preventing osteoporosis in older adults?
questions.rationale: Weight-bearing exercise (walking, jogging, dancing) stimulates osteoblast activity and helps maintain bone density.

questions.q: An older adult taking multiple medications should:
options: Use one pharmacy for all prescriptions
Share medications with a spouse on similar regimens
Only take medications when feeling ill
questions.rationale: Using one pharmacy allows the pharmacist to screen for drug interactions across all medications the patient takes.

questions.q: Which statement about sexuality in older adults is TRUE?
options: Older adults have no need for sexual health education
Sexual function may change but sexual interest often continues
Only men maintain sexual interest in old age
questions.rationale: Sexual interest and activity can continue throughout life. Physical changes may alter function but do not eliminate desire or capability.

questions.q: An important safety assessment for an older adult living alone includes:
options: Home environment evaluation for fall risks
Whether they can drive at night
questions.rationale: Home safety assessment identifies fall hazards (loose rugs, poor lighting, clutter) that are the leading cause of injury in older adults.

questions.q: Social isolation in older adults increases the risk of:
questions.rationale: Social isolation is associated with increased risk of depression, cognitive decline, cardiovascular disease, and mortality in older adults.

questions.q: According to Erikson, the developmental task for older adults is:
questions.rationale: Erikson's final stage: Integrity vs Despair. Older adults reflect on life — achieving integrity (satisfaction) or despair (regret).

questions.q: A 78-year-old patient says, 'I wasted my life.' This suggests unresolved:
questions.rationale: Expressing regret about one's life reflects despair in Erikson's final developmental stage.

questions.q: Life review (reminiscence therapy) in older adults is used to:
options: Help achieve ego integrity by reflecting on life experiences
questions.rationale: Reminiscence therapy helps older adults find meaning and achieve ego integrity by reviewing and sharing life experiences.

questions.q: The disengagement theory of aging proposes that:
options: Older adults should stay as active as possible
Withdrawal from society is a natural part of aging
Social engagement prevents all cognitive decline
questions.rationale: Disengagement theory (Cumming & Henry) suggests mutual withdrawal between the aging individual and society is natural and functional.

questions.q: The activity theory of aging proposes that:
options: Continued social activity promotes successful aging
questions.rationale: Activity theory suggests that staying physically, mentally, and socially active leads to greater life satisfaction in older adults.

questions.q: The wear-and-tear theory of aging suggests:
options: Cells deteriorate from accumulated damage over time
The immune system attacks the body
questions.rationale: The wear-and-tear (stochastic) theory proposes that aging results from cumulative damage to cells and tissues over a lifetime.

questions.q: Ageism refers to:
options: Discrimination or prejudice based on age
questions.rationale: Ageism is discrimination, stereotyping, or prejudice directed toward individuals based on their age — a significant issue in healthcare.

questions.q: A young nurse says, 'All old people are confused.' This is an example of:
questions.rationale: This is a stereotypical generalization (ageism). Confusion is NOT a normal part of aging and always requires assessment for underlying cause.

questions.q: Reproductive changes in older women include:
questions.rationale: Decreased estrogen after menopause causes vaginal atrophy, dryness, and thinning of vaginal walls.

questions.q: Reproductive changes in older men include:
options: Enlarged prostate (BPH) and slower erectile response
questions.rationale: Aging men experience decreased testosterone, prostatic enlargement (BPH), and slower but not absent erectile response.

questions.q: Which medication adjustment is commonly needed in older adults?
options: Higher doses due to increased metabolism
Lower starting doses ('start low, go slow')
questions.rationale: 'Start low, go slow' is the cardinal rule of geriatric pharmacology due to decreased metabolism and clearance.

questions.q: NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) should be used cautiously in older adults because of:
options: No adverse effects in this population
Increased risk of GI bleeding and renal impairment
questions.rationale: NSAIDs increase risk of GI bleeding, renal impairment, and cardiovascular events in older adults and are on the Beers Criteria.

questions.q: An older adult taking a diuretic should be monitored for:
options: Dehydration, orthostatic hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances
questions.rationale: Diuretics can cause dehydration, orthostatic hypotension (fall risk), hypokalemia, and hyponatremia in older adults.

questions.q: Which nursing intervention promotes sleep in an older adult WITHOUT medication?
questions.rationale: Sleep hygiene measures: consistent bedtime, warm bath, reduced evening stimulation, avoid caffeine — all promote natural sleep.

questions.q: Reality orientation for confused older adults involves:
options: Providing clocks, calendars, and consistent staff
questions.rationale: Reality orientation uses environmental cues (clocks, calendars, consistent caregivers) to help orient confused patients.

questions.q: Validation therapy is MOST appropriate for patients with:
questions.rationale: Validation therapy acknowledges and empathizes with the dementia patient's feelings and reality rather than correcting or reorienting them.

questions.q: The BEST way to prevent delirium in hospitalized older adults is:
options: Early mobilization, adequate hydration, and reorientation
Keeping the room dark and quiet at all times
questions.rationale: The HELP (Hospital Elder Life Program) protocol uses mobilization, hydration, orientation, and sleep enhancement to prevent delirium.

questions.q: Cataracts are treated by:
questions.rationale: Cataract surgery (phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implant) is the definitive treatment and is one of the most common surgeries in older adults.

questions.q: An older adult with macular degeneration will FIRST notice:
options: Central vision loss and distorted straight lines
questions.rationale: Macular degeneration affects the central retina (macula), causing loss of central vision used for reading, driving, and recognizing faces.

questions.q: The Amsler grid is used to detect:
questions.rationale: The Amsler grid tests for central vision distortion (wavy, missing lines) characteristic of macular degeneration.
